## Introduction

These two videos present two examples of how you might actually implement a Carnot cycle in the physical world.

- **Part 1** presents the air-standard Carnot cycle.
- Part 2 presents the steam Carnot cycle.

::: {.fragment}
We will use these two examples as the basis for all of the power and refrigeration cycles we will study. 
:::

::: {.column width="78%"}

A Carnot engine operates between two isothermal heat reservoirs and produces the greatest possible work while rejecting the minimum amount of heat. The efficiency of a Carnot engine is:

:::{.fragment}
$$\eta \equiv \frac{|W|}{|Q_\mathrm{hot}|} = 1 - \frac{T_\mathrm{cold}}{T_\mathrm{hot}}$$
:::
:::{.fragment}
The four steps of any Carnot engine are:
:::
:::{style="font-size: 92px;"}
1. Adiabatic temperature change from $T_\mathrm{cold}$ to $T_\mathrm{hot}$
2. Isothermal heat addition of $Q_\mathrm{hot}$ at $T_\mathrm{hot}$
3. Adiabatic temperature change from $T_\mathrm{hot}$ to $T_\mathrm{cold}$
4. Isothermal heat removal of $Q_\mathrm{cold}$ at $T_\mathrm{cold}$
:::

:::
::::

## Air-standard Carnot cycle

:::{.fragment}
The steps of the Carnot cycle
:::
:::{style="font-size: 98px;"}
1. Adiabatic compression from $T_\mathrm{cold}$ to $T_\mathrm{hot}$ (State $a$ to State $b$).
2. Isothermal heat addition (State $b$ to State $c$).
3. Adiabatic expansion from $T_\mathrm{hot}$ to $T_\mathrm{cold}$ (State $c$ to State $d$).
4. Isothermal heat removal (State $d$ to State $a$).
:::

:::{.fragment}
For air-standard assume:
:::
:::{.fragment}
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A. Ideal Gas
:::
:::{.fragment}
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;B. $C_v = \dfrac{5}{2}R \implies C_p = \dfrac{7}{2}R$
:::
:::{.fragment}
[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}
[For step 1]{.underline} [(Review from *The Isochronicles: This First Law Saga Is a Gas*)]{style="font-size: 60px;"}
:::
:::{.fragment}
Closed system adiabatic reversible.
:::

##

**1^st^ Law**

::: {.fragment}
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$\Delta U = W$
:::
::: {.fragment}
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$nC_v \Delta T = W$
:::
::: {.fragment}
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$W = nC_v (T_\mathrm{hot} - T_\mathrm{cold})$
:::
[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}

::: {.fragment}
How about $P$ and $\hat{V}$?
:::
::: {.fragment}
If $\Delta S = 0$ (why?)
:::
[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}

::: {.fragment}
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$\left(\dfrac{P_b}{P_a}\right)^{\frac{R}{C_p}} = \dfrac{T_\mathrm{hot}}{T_\mathrm{cold}}$
:::

::: {.fragment}
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$P\hat{V}=RT$
:::

##

So

::: {.fragment}
$$\frac{\hat{V}_a}{\hat{V}_b} = \left(\frac{P_b}{P_a}\right)^{\frac{C_p - R}{C_p}}$$
:::
::: {.fragment}
or

$$P_a\hat{V}_a^\gamma = P_b\hat{V}_b^\gamma = \mathrm{constant}$$
:::
::: {.fragment}
where

$$\gamma \equiv \frac{C_p}{C_v} = \frac{C_p}{C_p - R}$$
:::

## 

[For Step 2]{.underline}

::: {.fragment}
1^st^ Law â€“ closed system isothermal
:::

::: {style="padding-left: 150px;"}
::: {.fragment}
$\Delta U = Q + W$
:::
::: {.fragment}
$\Delta U = 0$ (Why?)
:::
::: {.fragment}
$Q = -W$
:::
::: {.fragment}
$W = -n\int\limits_{P_i}^{P_f}Pd\hat{V}$
:::
:::

::: {.fragment}
Since

::: {style="padding-left: 150px;"}
$P=\dfrac{RT}{\hat{V}}$
:::

::: {.fragment}
::: {style="padding-left: 150px;"}
$W = -nRT\int\limits_{\hat{V}_i}^{\hat{V}_f} \dfrac{d\hat{V}}{\hat{V}} = nRT \ln \dfrac{\hat{V}_i}{\hat{V}_f} = nRT \ln \dfrac{P_f}{P_i} = -Q$
:::
:::
:::

## 

[For Step 3]{.underline}

[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}

::: {.fragment}
Adiabatic expansion
:::

[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}

::: {style="padding-left: 150px;"}
::: {.fragment}
$W = nC_v (T_\mathrm{cold} - T_\mathrm{hot})$
:::
:::

[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}

::: {.fragment}
[For Step 4]{.underline}
:::

[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}

::: {.fragment}
Isothermal cooling
:::

[</br>]{style="font-size: 40px;"}

::: {style="padding-left: 150px;"}
::: {.fragment}
$W  = nRT \ln \dfrac{\hat{V}_i}{\hat{V}_f} = nRT \ln \dfrac{P_f}{P_i} = -Q$
:::
:::

## 

The videos, *Cycle Wars: The Power Awakens and Cycle Wars: The Rise of Otto Cycles* explain air-standard cycles based on the air-standard Carnot cycle.

</br>

*Sadi Carnot and the Power of Fire, the 1824 Edition Part 2* presents the steam Carnot cycle.

## The Takeaways

1. The Carnot cycle consists of an isentropic temperature rise, an isothermal heat addition, an isothermal temperature drop, and an isothermal heat removal.
2. The air-standard Carnot cycle implements the four steps as an isentropic compression, an isothermal expansion, an isentropic expansion, and an isothermal compression.
3. The air-standard Carnot cycle efficiency can also be calculated in terms of the compression ratio and the pressure ratio.
